description:
Acromyrmex echinatior is a species of leaf-cutting ant found in Central and South America. It is a member of the subfamily Myrmicinae, known for their ability to cultivate fungus gardens as their primary food source.

Acromyrmex echinatior is characterized by their large size, reaching up to 15 millimeters in length, and their distinctive physical features. They have a well-developed head with powerful mandibles, used for cutting and carrying leaves, and a thorax with spines, which help protect them from predators.

These ants are known for their complex social organization, with a division of labor among different castes, including the queen, workers, and soldiers. They live in underground nests and are highly efficient at foraging for leaves, which they use to cultivate their fungus gardens.

Acromyrmex echinatior plays an important ecological role in their native habitats, contributing to the cycling of nutrients and the maintenance of plant diversity through their leaf-cutting activities. They are also of interest to researchers studying the evolution of complex social behavior and the interactions between ants and their fungal symbionts.
